Award.AwardTitle: NSF MRI: Acquisition of Long Read DNA Sequencing Instrument
Award.AbstractNarration: This Major Research Instrumentation award funds the acquisition of a long-read sequencing instrument employing a novel single molecule synthesis data acquisition system to dramatically accelerate genomic sciences at the University of Delaware (UD). A diverse cross section of research disciplines benefit from the acquisition of the sequencer, including: microbiology, soil science, oceanography, plant biology and genomics, animal science and genomics, cell biology, biochemistry, and bioinformatics. The sequencer aids joint research and multiple-investigator projects in several UD research centers and institutes including: the Delaware Environmental Institute, the Center for Environmental Genomics, the Avian Biosciences Center, a new Center for Bioinformatics and Computational Biology, and the Delaware Biotechnology Institute. Thus, the new sequencer directly supports faculty research across four colleges at UD and serves as an available resource for collaborators and researchers at regional institutions, thereby benefitting UD partners in EPSCoR and other programs. In addition, the sequencer is used to advance both graduate and undergraduate education and research, especially student training in genomics and metagenomics. The results of these research and teaching efforts will be broadly disseminated through a dedicated WWW-site, abstracts, and peer reviewed publications, as well as by active participation of students and faculty at professional meetings.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Delaware (UD) was awarded this instrumentation grant in August, 2010. The Pacific Biosciences RS system (PacBio) funded by this grant was installed at UD in September, 2011. Since that time, the instrument has been upgraded several times to improve the hardware, software and chemistry improvements. This has provided our sequencing center with advanced DNA sequencing capabilities that designed to increase the read length and improve accuracy.  Our university has built a strong reputation in utilizing and implementing high-throughput sequencing (HTS) technologies, as well as supporting rapid and cost-effective access to these technologies for international life science investigators.

    We have performed hundreds of DNA sequencing “runs” on the instrument. The high-quality data were used for a wide range of experimental analyses, including DNA analysis of many different prokaryotes, archea, algae, fungi, bacteriophage, a number of different plant species, predatory wasp, metagenomic samples, PCR amplicons, cDNA and bacterial artificial chromosomes (BACs). The data generated from these samples has thus far been used for resequencing of reference DNA, de novo assembly, polymorphism analysis, and metagenomic analysis.

     The current operational status of the PacBio ensures routine, rapid, and flexible access to high-throughput DNA sequencing technologies for genomic analysis. Our experience with this technology has facilitated method development and the flexible application of these methods to diverse projects. The PacBio will provide ongoing opportunities for investigators to conduct experimental research in genomics, metagenomics and epigenomics.


Last Modified: 10/17/2013
Modified by: Blake C Meyers

We have performed hundreds of DNA sequencing "runs" on the instrument. The high-quality data were used for a wide range of experimental analyses, including DNA analysis of many different prokaryotes, archea, algae, fungi, bacteriophage, a number of different plant species, predatory wasp, metagenomic samples, PCR amplicons, cDNA and bacterial artificial chromosomes (BACs). The current operational status of the PacBio ensures routine, rapid, and flexible access to high-throughput DNA sequencing technologies for genomic analysis. Our experience with this technology has facilitated method development and the flexible application of these methods to diverse projects.
